title: 109_s3490
content: The Act is titled the "Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge Study Act" and includes findings. Congress finds that the scenic Cherry Valley area in northeastern Pennsylvania is home to over 80 special-concern animal and plant species, including 6 endangered or threatened species such as the bog turtle, dwarf wedge mussel, and bald eagle. Additionally, Cherry Valley provides habitat for 79 species of national or regional concern. Cherry Valley is home to special-concern species like neotropical migratory birds, waterfowl, rare plants, and anadromous fish. The Kittatinny Ridge serves as an important migration route for birds of prey, including bald eagles and golden eagles. The ridge also includes a segment of the Appalachian Trail. The Kittatinny Ridge in Cherry Valley includes the Appalachian Trail and rare wildlife habitats like calcareous wetlands. Ongoing studies show high water quality in Cherry Creek. There is local support for a potential Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, with federal parcels like the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area and a segment of the Appalachian Trail owned by the National Park Service. Local communities, conservation entities, and landowners support the establishment of Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, viewing it as a complement to existing conservation efforts. Some landowners have already placed their land into conservation easements. Several local landowners have placed their land into conservation easements or other arrangements, supported by voter-approved open space and municipal land conservation funds in Monroe County, Pennsylvania. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "map," "Secretary," and "Study Area." SEC. 4. STUDY OF REFUGE POTENTIAL AND FUTURE REFUGE LAND ACQUISITION. The Secretary will conduct a study to evaluate the Study Area for potential acquisition by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service for inclusion in a potential Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. Consultation with State and local officials, private conservation organizations, and major landowners will be done to identify eligible land and determine acquisition boundaries. The Secretary will also determine if the Study Area is suitable for inclusion in the National Wildlife Refuge. The Secretary will assess the suitability of the Study Area for inclusion in the National Wildlife Refuge System and management according to relevant policies. They will also evaluate the conservation benefits of establishing a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, including preserving diverse wildlife populations, protecting habitats, and providing opportunities for wildlife-dependent recreation and research. The Secretary will assess the Study Area for inclusion in the National Wildlife Refuge System, focusing on conservation benefits, wildlife populations, habitat protection, and recreational opportunities. The Secretary shall acquire up to 30,000 acres of land, water, and interests in the Study Area and submit a report to Congress within one year of the enactment of the Act. The report to Congress will include a map identifying specific land and water for acquisition by the Secretary for a potential Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, a cost estimate for the acquisition, and an estimate of funds from non-Federal sources. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Secretary to carry out the acquisition and management of land, water, and interests in the Study Area, with $200,000 authorized to be appropriated.
